title: There Is a Word or Several, Must Be – Analytical Questions (Band 5)
author: Kathleen Spivak
poem:
There Is a Word or Several, Must Be – Kathleen Spivak

Breathe these words in all languages before they’re lost, thank you and mean it. The things we take for granted and now have abandoned us. Or will. Water, air, rich earth beneath the rubble, thank you for our daily breath. Give us this day. Exhale the little thank you words, they’re quick, slip out of our pores, clean hair. A shower. Soap and aspirin. Thank you. Whoever “you” might be. Appreciation. A survival skill we never get to hone enough. Thank you, For life. For health, for the newborn baby slipping out between the hips. For wondrous eyes and little rosebud fists, thank you, sweet pea. And jump ropes, patience, teachers of the world, and teach me self-control. Migration, vanishing, the butterflies, the orange peach of the oriole. Whatever bright-eyed bird you once saw flicker past and wondered what was that? You were lucky to have it show itself. You are lucky perhaps to be it, plumage, proud breast and wings. Thank you for shelter, the blanket of morning. Of this morning. When first frost found naked earth, or when you found that one shade tree in the desert of last summer. Sun like a knife blade, now the reluctant release of pain, those precious moments when it goes away. Do you still remember having such moments? There is a word or several, must be, in all the language, for saying thank you in a world of swirl. Thank you for not yet abandoning me, my body. Wait a bit. Yes please.

questions.question: How does the repetition of 'thank you' throughout the poem shape its overall tone?
options: It emphasizes the poet’s confusion and anger
It creates a rhythm of humble gratitude and reflection
It shows the speaker’s sarcasm toward life
It makes the poem sound monotonous and cold
questions.answer: It creates a rhythm of humble gratitude and reflection

questions.question: What is the effect of the line 'Breathe these words in all languages before they’re lost'?
options: It celebrates translation as a creative act
It encourages readers to learn new languages
It mocks the complexity of communication
It warns of cultural and linguistic extinction tied to loss of gratitude
questions.answer: It warns of cultural and linguistic extinction tied to loss of gratitude

questions.question: By listing simple items like 'soap and aspirin,' the poet highlights:
options: The abundance of luxury goods
The beauty of ordinary comforts often overlooked
The consumerism of modern life
The poet’s frustration with illness
questions.answer: The beauty of ordinary comforts often overlooked

questions.question: When Spivak writes 'Whoever “you” might be,' what does this reveal about her view of gratitude?
options: That gratitude transcends religious or specific belief systems
That she only believes in self-directed gratitude
That she is uncertain who deserves thanks
That she rejects the concept of thankfulness entirely
questions.answer: That gratitude transcends religious or specific belief systems

questions.question: What contrast does the poet establish through images of 'butterflies' and 'rubble'?
options: The separation of nature from human life
The poet’s loss of imagination
The fading of childhood memories
The fragility of beauty amid destruction
questions.answer: The fragility of beauty amid destruction

questions.question: The phrase 'Sun like a knife blade' most strongly suggests:
options: The healing power of sunlight
A peaceful natural image
The brilliance of a new beginning
The sharpness of pain and harshness of life
questions.answer: The sharpness of pain and harshness of life

questions.question: In the line 'Thank you for shelter, the blanket of morning,' what literary device is used?
options: Simile comparing dawn to fabric
Metaphor equating morning with warmth and protection
Hyperbole to exaggerate gratitude
Irony suggesting morning brings danger
questions.answer: Metaphor equating morning with warmth and protection

questions.question: How does Spivak’s tone shift near the end of the poem?
options: From calm reflection to violent anger
From joy to sarcasm about human nature
From sadness to complete indifference
From broad gratitude to personal vulnerability and fear of mortality
questions.answer: From broad gratitude to personal vulnerability and fear of mortality

questions.question: What is suggested by the poet’s final plea, 'Thank you for not yet abandoning me, my body'?
options: A humorous comment on aging
A focus on health and fitness
A rejection of physical existence
A recognition of life’s fragility and the body’s temporary loyalty
questions.answer: A recognition of life’s fragility and the body’s temporary loyalty

questions.question: Overall, the poem encourages readers to view gratitude as:
options: An essential act of survival and human connection
A religious duty to a specific deity
A meaningless habit of politeness
A response to pain and punishment
questions.answer: An essential act of survival and human connection
